results.title: Eyes of Laura Mars [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Irvin Kershner, Jon Peters and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Laura Mars is a high profile fashion photographer who specialises in settings of urban murder and violence. When she becomes plagued by visions of “real” murders, Laura dismisses them as a by-product of her work. However, tension starts to mount when she begins to telepathically witness the bloody murders of her friends and colleagues, as seen through the eyes of the actual killer. Cast includes: Faye Dunaway, Tommy Lee Jones, Brad Dourif, Rene Auberjonois and Raul Julia.

results.title: 8 1/2 = Eight and a half [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Angelo Rizzoli, Francinex and Cineriz
results.brief_description: After the international success of “La Dolce Vita” Fellini found himself in the position of an “overnight sensation”, with critics, audiences and cinema producers expecting his next film to be even more of a success. His predicament caused him to experience a self-doubting of his intellect and creativity, a self-doubt that he managed to commit to screen in this wonderful film. For “8 1/2” is about the struggle to create cinema; about the financial, creative, physical and mental exertions needed to produce a film. Marcello Mastroianni plays a film director, Guido Anselmi, who is beset by adoring fans, angry mistresses, nervous financial backers and hostile critics while in the process of directing his current film. Mixing autobiography, fantastical dream sequences, imaginative sets and starkly photographed childhood memories, “8 1/2” is the most entertaining and stimulating film ever made about film-making. Cast includes Claudia Cardinale, Anouk Aimee and Barbara Steele. Music score by Nino Rota. Voted second best film ever made by a “Sight and Sound” international poll in 1992. The film won the Best Foreign Film Oscar in 1963.

results.title: Bread and tulips = Pane e tulipani
results.creator_credit: Silvio Soldini, Daniele Maggioni and Monogatari
results.brief_description: Bread and tulips is an Italian comedy directed by Silvio Soldini, starring his wife, Licia Maglietta. It is the story of Rosalba, a suburban housewife, living in Pescara, Italy with her two teenage sons and boorish husband. On a tour of Italy with her family Rosalba is accidentally left behind at a depot as the bus departs without her. Dismayed that her family could allow this to happen, Rosalba heads back to Pescara, but on a whim decides to take a side trip to Venice, a city she has always longed to see. Once there, Rosalba begins to question the meaning of her life and the role that she plays in the family unit. Rosalba takes up residency in Vencie, engaging with many colourful characters including, Fernando Girasoli (Bruno Ganz), a depressed Finnish waiter, who offers Rosalba a place to stay and Grazia, (Marina Massironi), his eccentric neighbour, a holistic masseuse. Meanwhile, back in Pescara, Rosalba’s domineering husband, who is not coping domestically in her absence, sends an amateur sleuth (Guiseppe Battiston) to search for her. Shot on location in Venice, “Bread and tulips” explores notions of identity and of discovering the meaning of life. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Extreme prejudice
results.creator_credit: Walter Hill, Buzz Feitshans, Tri-Star Pictures and Carolco Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Walter Hill helms this macho neo-Western with aplomb, providing a plethora of violence and mayhem, in the style of Sam Peckinpah (Hill worked as a screenwriter on several Peckinpah films). Nick Nolte plays Jack Benteen, a Texas Ranger with an incendiary attitude (that apes Dirty Harry), driven by the lawlessness and brutality that has invaded his hometown since the drug trade has escalated there. Heading a key operation is former friend, Cash Bailey; Cash and Benteen are in love with the same sexy Mexican woman, currently Benteen’s girlfriend, which incenses their conflict. Benteen’s success in disarming his former friend is limited and he is countered by a crack team of mercenaries, all ex-army and officially dead or missing, who have been engaged to eliminate Cash and his merciless crew. The bloodshed in this film is quite relentless, lots of bullet-riddled bodies and big guns, interspersed with numerous high tech crimes. Hill tries to keep the central conflict interesting but the variety of sub-plots and the many scenes of testosterone fuelled vicious encounters, muddies the narrative focus.

results.title: Living out loud [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard LaGravenese, Stacey Sher, Michael Shamberg, Danny DeVito, Jersey Films and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Living out loud was the directorial debut for screenwriter, Richard LaGravenese, who based this script on two stories by Anton Chekhov. Judith Nelson is a genteel uptown New Yorker, devastated by the news that her husband is leaving her for another woman. The aftershocks of this event forces Judith to question her personal presumptions and life choices that lead her to this juncture. We witness Judith’s inner turmoil, coming to terms with the lie of her marriage and the challenge to find an identity, other than wife, which will enable her to relate to others. A part of Judith’s journey is the blossoming of her friendship with Pat, the elevator operator in her building who is deeply indebted to shady gamblers, estranged from his wife and facing the death of his young daughter. Judith’s financial assistance of Pat and potential romance, as well as her friendship with a sultry nightclub singer, directs her on a path that crystallises her ambitions. This is a sensitively written film, impressive in its observations of the emotional lives of the protagonists and the struggles that ensue.

results.title: The Awful truth
results.brief_description: One of the classic screwball comedies of the 1930s, “The Awful truth” was nominated for six Academy Awards, winning an Oscar for director Leo McCarey. This was the third time the story had been brought to the screen, this version particularly working because of the improvisation encouraged of the cast and crew. The actors’ state of bewilderment and the humour born from this is reinforced by the fact that much of their dialogue is ad-libbed. The story centres around New York couple the Warriners (Cary Grant and Irene Dunne), who both suspect the infidelities of the other. They agree to a trial divorce, but cannot agree on who will get custody of their pet dog Mr Smith. What follows is a battlefield of witty dialogue, slapstick, sophisticated New York versus Southern manners and sublime bickering, while the Warriners attempt to sabotage each other’s new romances and ultimately try to reunite.

results.title: How to steal a million
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Fred Kohlmar and World Wide Productions
results.brief_description: How to steal a million is a romantic comedy caper film that re-teams star Audrey Hepburn and director William Wyler thirteen years after their classic film “Roman holiday” was made. “How to steal a million” is set among the high-end fine art world of museums, collectors, dealers and con-artists. Audrey Hepburn plays Nicole Bonnet, who’s father Charles (Hugh Griffith) specialises in art fraud, in particular ‘lost’ van Gogh masterpieces, which go on to command high prices at auction. Charles’ prized (fake) Cellini sculpture, Venus, is loaned for a public exhibition in Paris. Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.

results.title: I Love you to death
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Kasdan, Ron Moler, Jeffrey Lurie, Tri-Star Pictures and Chestnut Hill Productions
results.brief_description: Joey Boca is a philandering pizza shop owner whose wife Rosalie turns a blind eye to his indiscretions until she spies him fondling a woman in the library aisles. Her initial reaction is to contemplate suicide, but her mother advises otherwise - eliminate the rat and be done with it. So Rosalie and her mother set about finding a killer, but their inept choices result in failure and a comedy of errors. Despite repeated attempts using a variety of methods, Joey appears to be invincible. Directed with bland efficiency by Lawrence Kasdan (The Big chill, The Accidental tourist, Grand Canyon, French kiss), this is a black comedy that ponders notions of fidelity and loyalty, albeit in a screwball manner. The original script is peppered with agreeable jokes but strains too hard to convince the audience that despite its dark premise, the filmmakers are only joking. The bright spot here is the ensemble cast in a range of unusual guises: William Hurt as a bummed out hippie, River Phoenix as a love sick would be murderer, Kevin Kline as a two-timing Italian. Based on a true story. Cast also includes Keanu Reeves, Tracey Ullman and Heather Graham.

results.title: Barbarella [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roger Vadim, Dino De Laurentiis, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Marianne Productions
results.brief_description: This cult film by New Wave director Roger Vadim begins with a flawlessly executed zero gravity strip-tease by the film’s feisty 41st century space adventurer, Barbarella (Jane Fonda). The adventure begins when the president of Earth contacts Barbarella for her help in locating Durand Durand (Milo O’Shea), a young scientist who has vanished with a deadly positronic ray that contains the power to “shatter the loving union of the universe”. Her mission takes an unexpected twist after her fur-lined vessel makes a forced landing on the icy planet Lythion after being rocked by a magnetic disturbance. Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.

constellations_other.name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture
constellations_other.description: Humans have long imagined the future, including prospective travel to space and what living life away from planet earth could look like. This extending to designing interiors of domestic spaces and how these have then influenced the aesthetics of screen culture through set building and design.

Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.

results.title: Breathless = A bout de souffle [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Georges de Beauregard, Imperia, Productions Georges de Beauregard and Societe Nouvelle de Cinematographie
results.brief_description: When the “young Turks” from the journal Cahiers du Cinema began making films in the late fifties, they revolutionised cinema by celebrating the look and attitudes of American pop-culture (B-movies, rock and roll) while infusing their own films with the uncertainties of a then distinctly European intellectual scrutiny. In “Breathless” a young hood kills a cop and goes on the run in Paris, hiding at his girlfriend’s flat until she betrays him. That’s life. Kiss-kiss, bang-bang. Playful, cool, name-dropping and audacious the film is true to its title, furiously exploring the possibilities of cinema while acknowledging its aesthetic debt to the low-budget films of Hollywood’s B-directors. Godard’s film remains the most influential of the French New Wave, and as the decade was to progress, Vietnam, Algiers and Maoism were to demand of him a more intellectually dense cinema. But in “Breathless” he is still the cheeky precocious brat, thumbing his nose at the world and inventing a new kind of film. From an original treatment by Francois Trauffaut, and with Claude Charbrol as artist and technical adviser. With Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg.
